Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Second-Generation HydroCoil Embolic System vs. Bare Platinum Coil in Intracranial Aneurysms

Background: Aneurysm recurrence after coiling is associated with growth, (re)hemorrhage, and increased follow-up. The second-generation HydroCoil Embolic System (HES) was developed to reduce recurrence by enhancing packing density and healing.

Methods: This randomised, controlled trial enrolled 600 subjects with 3-14 mm ruptured or unruptured intracranial aneurysms across 46 centers in the US and Canada. Participants were randomised 1:1 to HES (n=297) or bare platinum coil (BPC, n=303) using stratified randomisation by site. The primary outcome was aneurysm recurrence on the Raymond-Roy scale over 24 months. Secondary outcomes included minor/major recurrence, packing density, adverse events, mortality, initial occlusion, retreatment, hemorrhage, and clinical outcome. Imaging assessors were blinded, but patients and clinicians were not.

Results: Recurrence occurred in 11 (4.4%) HES and 44 (15.4%) BPC subjects (OR 3.97, 95% CI [1.99, 7.92], p=0.002). Initial occlusion was higher with BPC, but HES showed better packing density and lower recurrence rates. Adverse events were similar: 286 (47.9%) in HES and 311 (52.1%) in BPC. Serious adverse events were 92 (52.0%) in HES and 85 (48.0%) in BPC. Mortality was 7 (2.4%) in HES and 9 (3.0%) in BPC. Retreatment, hemorrhage, and clinical outcomes did not differ significantly between groups.

Interpretation: HES reduced recurrence without increased harm, supporting its use for embolizing small-to-medium intracranial aneurysms.

Trial registration: NCT01407952

Funding: MicroVention, Inc.
